message.content: This question requires logical reasoning and understanding of tree growth and the impact of infrastructure on plant roots. As the oak tree grows taller, its roots need to extend in order to support its increasing size and absorb nutrients from the soil. If the sidewalk is paved right next to the tree, the roots may encounter the concrete barrier. Over time, the roots may exert pressure on the concrete, causing it to crack and break. Option (A) is incorrect because roots falling apart is not a likely outcome. Option (B) is also incorrect because the roots need to extend to ensure the tree's survival. Option (D) is unlikely because roots do not typically split, but rather grow and branch out.

This question requires understanding of the growth and development of trees and the physical properties of concrete. As an oak tree grows taller, its roots continue to grow and extend in order to support the tree and bring in nutrients from the ground. When the roots reach the sidewalk, they may exert pressure on the concrete. Over time, this pressure can cause the concrete to crack or break, allowing the roots to continue growing. Option (A) is incorrect because roots do not "fall apart" when they encounter a sidewalk. Option (B) is incorrect because roots do not die when they reach a sidewalk, but they may be restricted in their growth. Option (D) is incorrect because roots do not split when they encounter a sidewalk, but they may cause the concrete to crack or break.

This question requires some basic understanding of how tree roots interact with concrete sidewalks. As an oak tree grows, its roots continually expand and spread out in search of water and nutrients. If a sidewalk is paved right next to where the oak tree was planted, the roots will eventually encounter the concrete barrier. In order to continue growing, the roots will exert pressure on the concrete and may eventually break it apart. This is why option (C) - "parts may break the concrete" - is the correct answer. Option (A) is incorrect because roots falling apart is not a common occurrence. Option (B) is incorrect because the tree roots are not likely to die unless there is another factor, such as a lack of nutrients or water. Option (D) is also incorrect because splitting roots is not a common occurrence when they encounter a sidewalk.

Option (D) is incorrect because splitting roots is not a typical consequence of tree growth near a sidewalk; instead, the roots exert pressure on the concrete.
